title: cumnock teen who disqualified driving
story: NewsCumnock teen who was disqualified from driving stole car claiming he would fix it upHe stole a car on February 27 after agreeing to the owner he was going to fix it up and return it.&nbspShareByAyrshire Post14:38, 7 JUN 2018News (Image: Ayrshire Post)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 19-year-old man has been given unpaid work for stealing a car while disqualified from driving. Josh Makin of Barshare Road in Cumnock stole a car on February 27 after agreeing to the owner he was going to fix it up and return it. Ayr Sheriff Court heard on Tuesday, May 29 that when officers traced Makin, he openly admitted he had scrapped the car which was worth &pound300 - and that he was a banned driver until September this year. Solicitor Mhairi McMillan said Makin’s family were concerned about his mental health and his “wreckless and impulsive decision making.” Makin was sentenced to a community payback order of 18 months supervision and ordered to carry out 120 hours of unpaid work. He was also disqualified from holding and obtaining a license for 15 months.

title: drive through coffee shop petrol
story: NewsDrive-through coffee shop and petrol pumps could be built on busy main roadThe ‘Highway Services’ would be located at Bogend Toll near Symington and could create 30 jobs.&nbspShareBySarah Hilley14:45, 6 JUN 2018NewsA77 near Dutch House Roundabout (Image: Alister Firth/Ayrshire Post)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA drive-through coffee shop and petrol pumps are to be built on the A77 if plans get the green light. The ‘Highway Services’ would be located at Bogend Toll near Symington and could create 30 jobs. A Shell petrol station and Londis shop are part of the vision for the site. A raft of documents have been lodged with South Ayrshire Council as part of a planning application. London-based Grove Garages is behind the proposal, which would see two buildings erected.   The company has an agreement with Shell and Londis but is still in talks to sign-up a coffee firm.  The plan includes eight fuel pumps, 11 parking spaces, two car wash bays and pumps for HGVs.  The coffee shop would have a floor space of 260sqm with 29 car spaces and a drive through at the back. A supporting statement said: “The location of the site represents an ideal opportunity for a roadside servies area to cater for the frequent tourist, haulage and commuter traffic using the A77. It said the development would ensure the “reuse of a visually and environmentally poor site in a prominent location alongside one of Scotland’s main tourist routes, the A77.”  The site used to be a field belonging to Dyke Farm. Access to the site would be from the B730 adjoining the A77 north bound carriageway. Cars could enter from the southbound carriageway through the existing flyover. Chargers would also be available for electric cars. A design and access statement said: “The proposals give back purpose to an unused site, which has potential to provide an important service to the local area and indeed the wider area. The design proposals are considered to be respectful to the local environment and are in line with local policy and guidelines. No decision has been made on the application yet.

title: family vanessa riddle who lost
story: NewsFamily of Vanessa Riddle who lost fight to cancer hailed her 'inspirational and beautiful'Following a long battle with neuroblastoma, the 17-year-old died peacefully surrounded by dad Chris, mum Connie, and sister Olivia.&nbspShareByStuart Wilson08:40, 7 JUN 2018NewsVanessa Riddle with mum Connie and sister Olivia (Image: user submitted)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe devastated family of Vanessa Riddle have hailed their “inspirational and beautiful daughter” after she passed away on Friday. Following a long battle with neuroblastoma, the 17-year-old died peacefully surrounded by dad Chris, mum Connie, and sister Olivia. It was a fight that captured not just the hearts and minds of Ayrshire, but the world beyond. Vanessa, who displayed courage which belied her condition, would rarely be seen without a smile on her face. For almost a decade, her name became synonymous with the fight against the aggressive cancer. Almost &pound1million was raised with the aim of sending Vanessa abroad for life-saving treatment. That dream was realised and in January 2013, the family received the news they longed for – that the cancer was in remission.  Vanessa would return to school and rejoin classmates as a hugely popular figure at Marr College. Life, as normal as it could ever be, was good again for this inspirational girl. But the cancer would return and spread to Vanessa’s brain, with her family receiving the crushing news that her condition was terminal. As ever, Vanessa fought bravely until the last before she passed away just days short of her 18th birthday. Now her family are vowing that her fight will live on in her legacy. Dad Chris told the Post: “We are devastated at our loss.  “Vanessa was a huge inspiration to Connie, Olivia and I and so many more. “She achieved lots during her short but fulfilled life, she did everything she wanted to do and lived life to the full. “She never complained about anything, even though her situation was dire and she knew it. “We are privileged to have had such an inspirational and beautiful daughter.”  Vanessa’s funeral will take place on Friday, June 22 at 11.30am at Dreghorn Crematorium and then on to Troon Town Hall for a Celebration of Life. Chris added: “We’d like to ask that people wear bright colours and for the gents not to wear black ties. “That is what Vanessa would have wanted.”

title: lawrence shankland agrees new deal
story: NewsLawrence Shankland agrees new deal to stay at Ayr United for Championship pushThe 29-goal striker has put pen to paper on a new deal at Somerset Park.&nbspShareByStuart WilsonLochlin Highet13:14, 15 MAY 2018Updated13:18, 15 MAY 2018NewsShankland is staying on at Somerset (Image: Daily Record)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLawrence Shankland insists money can’t buy happiness after he sensationally spurned a host of lucrative offers to pen a new deal at Ayr United. The prolific striker turned down Premiership riches and clubs in England to agree a one-year contract at Somerset Park on Tuesday. Shankland, 22, told the Ayrshire Post: “It’s a great club to be a part of. The main thing for this decision is that I am enjoying my football. The gaffer has been great with me and that’s why I came here. He gave me a chance to get back into football. I am happy and I don’t think there’s any amount of money that beats happiness. The fans have taken to me and that gives you confidence going into every game you play. Shankland smashed 29 goals en route to being named League One's player of the year as Ayr won the title.  Boss Ian McCall said: Lawrence could have doubled his money elsewhere and had offers from the Premiership up here and League One down in England. But the affection he has had from our supporters has played a huge part in his decision. It’s a huge piece of business for this club. Be in no doubt that Lawrence could easily have gone, but he has made a footballing decision. It is a big, big signing which shows our intent and now we need the fans to respond with an upsurge in season ticket sales. title: meet weeks wedding week
story: NewsMeet this week's Wedding of the Week“We actually met about 15 years ago when both of us used to go ice skating at the Magnum on a Friday night,” said Kim.&nbspShareByAbi Smillie15:09, 6 JUN 2018NewsNewlyweds Kim and Craig celebrate with their wedding party and guests (Image: KSG Photography)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis week’s Wedding of the Week couple features Kimberley O’Connor, 29-year-old cardiology secretary at Crosshouse Hospital who married 30-year-old Craig McLauchlan, sales executive for Jaguar/Land Rover at Parks in Ayr. The couple now live in Kilmarnock. “We actually met about 15 years ago when both of us used to go ice skating at the Magnum on a Friday night,” said Kim. The pair lost touch over the years but were reunited six years ago. Kim said: “We started chatting as friends but it became apparent the spark was definitely still there between us and a few months later we moved in together. “It was a whirlwind romance - within a year of meeting we had moved in together, got engaged and had a beautiful baby boy.  “We then had another baby in 2016 and it was then we decided to start planning the wedding.” The couple tied the knot at The Vu in Bathgate on Mother’s Day, March 11 this year. Kim said: “We were a bit panicky about the weather as the week before the wedding was storm Edna and everyone was snowed in. “There was still some snow lying around on the wedding day but the sun was shining. “The wedding day was an emotional day from start to finish it was full of tears and laughter and genuinely was the best day of our lives!” The bride wore a Maggie Sottero ‘Lisette’ dress from Opus Couture in West Kilbride, as well as veil and hair piece. The kilts were from MacGregor &amp MacDuff in Prestwick.  The couple’s wedding party consisted of flowergirls - Daughters, Macie O’Donnell and Evie McLauchlan and bride’s sister Molly Miller Page boys were son, Alfie McLauchlan and bride’s brother Jack Miller and the best man was Groom’s brother-in-law, Richard Hunter. Kim continued: “We haven’t managed to get away on a honeymoon yet as we have three children so picking a destination has been quite difficult! “We do plan on going somewhere we just haven’t decided where yet.” KSG Photography captured the couple’s big day, leaving them with beautiful photos to look back on. Claire’s Crystal Brides arranged the bouquets with Ashley Nimmo and Jett Patterson of Allure Hair &amp Beauty, Kilmarnock created the hair and beauty looks for the day. Kim added: “Our cake was made by a friend who is a cake maker, Diane Kay. “We didn’t really have a clue about a cake so we just sent Diane some pictures and trusted her to make us a gorgeous cake and we were not disappointed!  “We had a white three tier cake with silver and diamant&eacute lace trim, it fitted the wedding theme perfectly and was absolutely delicious.” The couple added: “Thanks to all the staff at the Vu for an absolutely amazing day. “Kevin the photographer, Waterfront the band, Winton Weddings for our stunning decor, Susan from Opus Couture for helping me chose my stunning dress and all our friends and family who attended the wedding and made it the most perfect special day! “My best friend, Shelby McAllister for being right by my side for the full day and keeping me calm in the lead up to the wedding. “And last but not least - my Grampa Willie for walking me down the aisle and making all my dreams come true!” For more photos of this week’s Wedding of the Week, pick up your copy of the Ayrshire Post. title: prestwick tennis superstar learning disability
story: NewsPrestwick tennis superstar with learning disability climbed Goat Fell for charityDominic Iannotti, who is number one in the world for his tennis category, made it to the top of the 2867ft peak on Arran.&nbspShareByLochlin Highet14:45, 7 JUN 2018NewsDominic Iannotti Prestwick Tennis player (Image: Copyright Unknown)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRising tennis star Dominic Iannotti made a mountain of cash by climbing Goat Fell. The 20-year-old from Prestwick, who is number one in the world for his tennis category, made it to the top of the 2867ft peak on Arran. Dominic was diagnosed with Asperger syndrome, which is on the autism spectrum, at a young age and is part of the Great Britain Learning Disability tennis team. After three years in the sport, he is number one in the world for his doubles category and number three in the world for singles. He competes in the mainstream tennis ranks and is in the top 10 for the South/West Scotland overall. He is currently part of an apprenticeship at Prestwick Tennis Fitness Club and is close to achieving his level three coaching badges that would allow him to coach anywhere in the world. Dominic’s dad, Anthony, who runs the Iannotti Bros cash and carry, could not be more proud of him. The 50-year-old, from Prestwick, said: “Dominic was diagnosed at a young age. We tried all kinds of things but nothing seemed to help. “My wife went online and found children’s charity Bibic and we spoke to them. They were a godsend and they guided us and helped Dominic through a lot.    Since then we haven’t looked back and he has became a fantastic kid.  “You would never know he had this syndrome and that’s credit to the hard work done.” Dominic decided to give something back to the charities that have helped him over the years. He climbed Goat Fell with a group of friends and raised &pound810 for Bibic and South Ayrshire Autistic Society. Anthony said: “We are very proud of him. “A lot of people now do fundraising for national charities but the local ones don’t get as much exposure or sponsors. We wanted to help Bibic as they were instrumental in helping the way Dominic is today and SAAS helped Dominic from a very young age.”

title: south ayrshire council bosses urged
story: NewsSouth Ayrshire Council bosses urged to throw Ayr United a title partyCalls are mounting for civic head, Helen Moonie, to hold a bash at County Buildings, following Ayr’s first league title in 21 years.&nbspShareByStuart Wilson12:11, 9 MAY 2018NewsAyr United title celebrations (Image: SNS Group)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCouncil bosses have been urged to throw Ayr United’s champions an official party. Calls are mounting for civic head, Helen Moonie, to hold a bash at County Buildings, following Ayr’s first league title in 21 years. But the request could be snubbed in favour of a joint sporting celebration, the Post understands. A request for the engagement, lodged in the aftermath of Ayr’s success, is being considered by officials. Former cop Alasdair Malcolm, now a volunteer at Somerset Park, has called for the recognition. He said: “Every effort should be made to mark this fantastic achievement. “Ayr United are an integral part of the local community and, particularly through their Academy programme, have close working relationships throughout local schools and community groups. “The club, which has been a feature of the town since 1910, have had an outstanding season.” Ayr became the first club in the UK to score 100 goals in domestic competition en route to their title.  And their championship was the first to be clinched on home soil for 90 years. Mr Malcolm, secretary of the Ayrshire Golf Association, said: “It would be fitting if the local authority, by way of a civic reception or similar event, would mark the achievement of the management, players, officials and staff.” South Ayrshire Tory leader, Martin Dowey, added: “It is a wonderful achievement and one that is worthy of a civic reception. “A prosperous Ayr United is good for the town and we will be calling on all councillors to recognise the title win.” However, it’s believed there may be other invites on the guest list of any civic celebration. Carrick Rugby Club, three-time winners of the BT National Shield, and Commonwealth gold medallist Paul Foster, are among those in their thoughts. A council spokesman said: “A request has been received and will be considered in line with our civic hospitality guidelines.”

title: thousands pounds pocketed council after
story: NewsThousands of pounds pocketed by council after secret VAT grabBut they’ve been caught out by golfers incensed South Ayrshire Council has not passed on any benefit of a government zero VAT ruling on leisure.&nbspShareByStephen Houston14:18, 6 JUN 2018NewsCouncillor Peter Convery brands move on VAT “sleekit”&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThousands of pounds is being pocketed by a council after a secret VAT grab. But they’ve been caught out by golfers incensed South Ayrshire Council has not passed on any benefit of a government zero VAT ruling on leisure. In February HMRC announced there was to be no VAT on council provided leisure activities. And that will include swimming, gym use and bowling at Northfield. But South Ayrshire Council has not let any of its customers know. If effectively means golf charges have soared 24% on last year, rather than the 2.7% the council have boasted about. It means that golfers paying the &pound429 season ticket price would be expecting a &pound71.50 reduction for VAT.  Tory councillor Peter Convery is blasting the move as “sleekit.” And he said: “Surely people are entitled to get some money paid back to them? “This is about principle and this is sleekit. “This is peoples’ money and should never have been included in the original ticket charge. “It is very unfortunate the council cannot see this to any great extent.” In East Ayrshire, where leisure is provided by an arm’s length trust, VAT is necessary on charges. Details of the VAT grab emerged in an email between a golfer and Councillor Brian McGinley.  The golfer, who preferred to remain anonymous, said: “I do not think the majority of season ticket holders will be enamoured to discover that a significant element of their season ticket fee is actually related to a cost that SAC no longer have to bear.” Ayr East councillor McGinley said in the email: “I have ascertained that VAT has been included within the price of a season ticket up until February 18 this year. “Following a court ruling against HMRC whereby sports services provided by local authorities are now classed as exempt for VAT purposes, VAT is no longer remitted to HMRC when income is received for season tickets etc.” A council spokesman would not explain why they had not revealed the VAT windfall, if players can expect a refund or whether is was just being used to mask a huge leap in prices.  He would only say: “We work hard to ensure our golf and leisure provision continues to offer great value for local people and visitors and this is reflected in our current charging structure. “The funding from entry fees and season tickets only makes a partial contribution to our overall operating costs – with the remainder coming directly from Council subsidy – and the 2.7% price increase on last year’s fees reflects the Consumer Price Index. “Reducing inequalities within our communities is a key commitment for the Council and we have extended the concessions available under the Access to Leisure card scheme – which includes a 15% discount for all South Ayrshire residents. The change in VAT application for Council leisure services contributes towards the costs of that important scheme, which will help improve health and wellbeing across South Ayrshire, as well as helping reduce the net deficit cost of running Council leisure services, which was almost &pound11 million in 2016/17.”

title: troon church help build new
story: NewsTroon church to help build new school for hurricane victimsThe Troon church has raised £170,000 to help transform people’s lives in Haiti.&nbspShareBySarah Hilley14:28, 7 JUN 2018NewsPastor Richard Woods with Minister Rolex visiting Muirhead Primary (Image: Copyright unknown)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Building a school for hurricane victims was once a dream for Seagate Church.  Now it is a reality.  The Troon church has raised &pound170,000 to help transform people’s lives in Haiti. Building work on the new school will start in two weeks. Pastor Richard Woods and his congregation have been working tirelessly to help people in the town of Ouanaminthe. Pastor Woods said: “We are going out in August and we expect to see the school nearly finished by then. “It will be fantastic. We have exceeded our fundraising targets.” Three hundred children will be educated at the eight classroom school. There are also hopes to erect a church.   Seagate’s work has been supported by Troon schools.  Haiti minister Pastor Rolex Poisson attended assembly at Muirhead Primary and thanked pupils for their fundraising efforts.  Pastor Rolex has returned to the Caribbean with a contract for a builder to kick off construction. Meanwhile the charity endeavours in Troon are still going strong.  Next Saturday Richard’s daughter Lucy is planning a swim in Lake Windermere for the Haiti project.  The Struthers Primary pupil hopes to visit Haiti next summer.  To support Lucky visit: www.give.net/lucyshaitiswim. The Haiti project is being supported by the Church of Scotland Guild.

title: twilight walkers raise over 50k
story: NewsTwilight walkers raise over £50K for charityThe Ayrshire Hospice Starlight event has seen fundraising cash pouring in – with money still coming.&nbspShareByStuart Wilson13:44, 7 JUN 2018NewsAyr Grammar Primary staff took part in the Starlight Walk (Image: Ayrshire Post)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwilight walkers who hit the streets of Ayr have raised more than &pound50,000. The Ayrshire Hospice Starlight event has seen fundraising cash pouring in – with money still coming. Hundreds set off on the annual pilgrimage from Ayr Racecourse, which this year celebrated its tenth gig on the spin. Graham Strawhorn, the hospice’s fundraising officer, said: “We were once again very lucky with the weather and initial feedback from our walkers has been fabulous. “It will take time to receive sponsor money from all our walkers, however, I anticipate we will have raised in excess of &pound50,000, which is an amazing amount for the Hospice. “It’s always a fantastic moment when all our walkers, supporters and sponsors finally congregate pre-walk in the Ayrshire Suite at the racecourse for this unique event, supporting the hospice in their own special way.  “Whether it is in support of a relative, friend or colleague who suffers from life limiting illness or in celebration/in memory of a loved one, events like the Starlight Walk always show us how amazing our community support is. “When we look around the Ayrshire Suite each year, we are reminded of how many people are touched by our cause and we are, as always, deeply grateful for their support and their fantastic fundraising efforts.” Graham added: “As always, funds raised from events like the Starlight Walk will be used to help improve the quality of each day for our patients, helping them to live as actively as they can to the end of their lives – however long that may be and wherever that may be.” The hospice requires to raise &pound4.3 million each year to continue funding its critical service. Graham said: “The ongoing commitment, energy and passion from the community is humbling and is certainly support we couldn’t do without.” This year’s successful event was sponsored by Ayr Audi with support from the Ayrshire Post, Healthy Working Lives, Tesco, McKissock Electrical, The Cook School Scotland, Air Image Photography and South Ayrshire Council.

title: Scottish Borders Council to  pursue  land purchase of Lowood Estate
story:
SCOTTISH&nbspBorders Council has decided to conclude negotiations with the owners of Lowood Estate with the intention to acquire the land.
A successful acquisition would enable development proposals to be brought forward in line with the Local Development Plan, which was updated by the Council last year.
Councillors met today to discuss the proposal, a private item at the full Council meeting due to the inclusion of commercially sensitive information.
Local plans are informed by the Tweedbank Masterplan which identifies the potential for new residential and business space development on Lowood Estate, as part of a wider Tweedbank expansion proposal, which would seek to attract existing and new residents and businesses moving into the area, including those who would wish to use the nearby Borders Railway as a key transport mode.
The prospectus also identifies opportunities to expand Tweedbank village and reposition the current industrial estate as a new Borders Innovation Park.
The Tweedbank Masterplan was developed as part of the Borders Railway Blueprint Programme, and was carried out at the same time as a similar piece of work on Galashiels.&nbsp
Both these masterplans, which are available on the Council&rsquos website, present a variety of proposals to encourage people to live, learn, visit and work in the area, as well as attract inward investment through public and private investment and partnership working.
Councillor Mark Rowley, SBC&rsquos executive member for business and economic development, with responsibility for housing, said: &ldquoAny discussions and negotiations around the purchase of land is clearly commercially sensitive and therefore we cannot go into detail, however following discussions and background work over a period of time the Council has now taken the opportunity to get a decision from Elected Members to proceed to more formal negotiations with the owners of the estate.
&ldquoThere are clear benefits to this strategic site being in the Council&rsquos ownership and control in terms of facilitating the development of the land in line with the Local Development Plan and future proofing for the extension of the Borders Railway.
&ldquoClearly this is a long-term strategy, and negotiations around the potential purchase of the site are a first step, and one which must be handled sensitively and dealt with in private.

title: Biggest and best Junior Rideout yet in Selkirk
story:
ORGANISERS of the fourth Selkirk Junior Rideout have hailed the event as the biggest and best yet.
A record 96 young riders and their ponies took to the streets of the Royal Burgh on Wednesday.
And every one of them was given an enthusiastic welcome as Souters in their hundreds lined the route.
Standard Bearer Peter Forrest led the cavalcade from Station Road up The Green and into the picturesque Haining for a well-earned rest.
And as they remounted and headed down the Back Row, each and every one of the riders was presented with a badges and rosette by this year's Attendants before having photographs taken with the 2018 Standard Bearer.
Gordon Hislop from the organising Ex Standard Bearers Association, told us: "Standard Bearer Forrest was excellent with all of the riders.
"He took time to meet and chat with each of them as well as have his photo taken with them.
"Not only did we have the most riders we've ever had but the crowds who came out to see them were as big, if not bigger, than we've ever had before.
"It's fair to say the Junior Rideout is going from strength to strength."
After the presentations at the bottom of the Back Row, the cavalcade was led along the High Street and through the Market Place by Selkirk Silver Band, who for the the first time included its talented junior section.
Riders had come from afar as St Andrew's, Morpeth and Musselburgh as well as almost every Borders town to take part.
And they were rewarded with a night few of them will forget.
Mr Hislop added: "For many of the riders this will be their first taste of a Common Riding rideout.
"They are the next generation of riders who will one day ride the Marches and help continue our ancient traditions.
"The Junior Rideout is very much part of our Common Riding now and we hope it will continue for many years to come."
The Selkirk Ex Standard Bearers' Association would like to thank Scottish Borders Council for help is organising the event, Scottish Borders Housing Association for their financial support to purchase rosettes and badges, PC Conal McEwan for his unwavering support, Elliot and Sandra Murray for organising the foot stewards, Booker Cash and Carry for providing the riders' goody bags, and Broomhill Equestrian Centre for the horsey goody bags.

title: Over 1 400 vintage and classic vehicles to ride into Lauder this weekend
story:
DUBBED as one of the most popular events in the Borders, this year&rsquos BVAC Classic is set to have a record-breaking number of vehicles on display.
More than 1,400 vintage and classic vehicles and their proud owners will be making the journey to Thirlestane Castle in Lauder on Sunday, June 3, for the annual festival of motoring.
The event has been described by the Sunday Times as &lsquoThe best classic car festival in Scotland&rsquo from their list of Top Ten Car Events in the UK, and attracts thousands of visitors to one of the largest car rallies in the country.
Now in its 46th year, this year&rsquos show promises a vintage performance with something for everyone to admire and enjoy.
From veteran, vintage and classic cars to motorcycles, commercial, agricultural, military, steam and American classes, this year will see a special family car through the ages theme.
Land Rover, Lotus and 2CV all share a special anniversary year in 2018 and there will be unique displays of these very different vehicles on show as well as Italian classics in the shape of a special Concorso Italiano display.
Tickets
cost &pound10, with free entry for children under 16.

title: Tributes paid to former Gala Rugby player Nairn MacEwan
story:
FORMER Scotland coach Nairn MacEwan has died at the age of 76, the Scottish Rugby Union has announced, 
writes&nbspAndy Newport, Press Association Sport.
Capped 20 times as a player, he took over coaching the national team in 1977 at a time when the head coach's position was given the quaint title of "adviser to the captain".
MacEwan led the side for the next three years, before he was succeeded by JimTelfer.
His time in charge did not coincide with a golden era for the Scots, who failedto win a single match during the two Five Nations campaigns MacEwan presided over.
But the back-row forward's playing days did involve some more memorable moments, including four wins against England in the space of three years.
Born in Dar-es-Salaam in what is now Tanzania in December 1941, MacEwan's commitment to the game he loved was the stuff of legend.
He would often travel three times in a week, twice for training and then at the weekend for playing, from his home near Inverness to Galashiels in the Borders to turn out for club side Gala - a round trip of around 400 miles.
MacEwan won his first cap against France at the Stade Colombes in Paris in January 1971 and scored his only try for the Scots against the Auld Enemy in the 23-9 Murrayfield win of 1972.
After his stint in charge of Scotland ended, he had spells coaching in Ireland, Italy and Sweden.
A spokesman for Scottish Rugby Union said: "We extend our sincere condolences to all Nairn MacEwan's family and friends."

title: A Midsummer Night   s Dream comes to Abbotsford
story:
NATIONAL touring theatre company The Three Inch Fools are heading to to Abbotsford next month.
Acclaimed for their fast-paced and musically driven approach to Shakespeare, the company will bring lots of fun and frivolity to the home of Sir Walter Scott, on Friday, July 13.
Five actors, with all manner of musical instruments and plenty of character-swapping, will present an inventive take on Shakespeare&rsquos A Midsummer Night&rsquos Dream as part of their national summer tour.
Shakespeare&rsquos much-loved play is a comic tale of runaway lovers, beguiling potions and an unfortunate individual who gets turned into a donkey.
When four unfortunate lovers decide to elope into the woods, little do they know things are about to get a lot more complex.
Add to the mix a mischievous sprite and a motley crew of mechanicals attempting to rehearse a play, and anything could happen.
The five-strong company of Fools bring the magical world of the forest vividly to life in this new production, in a way that is certain to delight and surprise those already familiar with the play, and to enchant those who have yet to discover its joys.
Audience members are invited to arrive early, and to bring a picnic, to add to the festival atmosphere of the performance, and to make this a midsummer night&rsquos dream of their own.
&ldquoWe want to show Shakespeare off to everyone and excite a whole new generation of Shakespeare lovers to get to know his plays in all their vibrancy, says Three Inch Fools CoFounder and Director James Hyde.
"Through our own high-paced performance style and musical talents we would say we have found our own unique take on Shakespeare.
The Three Inch Fools specialise in bringing Shakespeare to life in innovative and unexpected ways, through bold choreography and mystical sound-worlds, working with award-winning composer Stephen Hyde.
Original music plays a central role in this production, cleverly helping to elevate Shakespeare&rsquos text from the page, and to recreate the same lively atmosphere that Elizabethan audiences would have experienced.
Over the years, The Three Inch Fools have performed in venues ranging from castles and cathedrals to bookshops and seaside piers &ndash all the world&rsquos a stage!
They are particularly excited to be returning to Abbotsford this year, performing one of Shakespeare&rsquos best-loved plays.
A Midsummer Night&rsquos Dream runs at Abbotsford on Friday, July 13 at 7pm.
Tickets
cost &pound14 (&pound12 concessions, &pound12.60 friends) and are available online from www.threeinchfools or www.scottsabbotsford .
Tickets can also be booked by phone on 01896 752043 or in person at the Abbotsford Visitor Centre.
Booking is essential as spaces are limited. Gates open for picnics from 6pm.

title: Scottish Borders Council pledges   3 1m for outdoor projects
story:
COUNCILLORS have approved a motion to spend &pound3.1 million to improve outdoor spaces in the Borders.
On Thursday elected members voted to earmark the cash to create outdoor play areas, skate parks and pump tracks over the next four years.
And it has been confirmed that Peebles, Harestanes, Kelso, Coldstream, Hawick, Jedburgh, Eyemouth and Earlston will be next in line for investment.
Councillor Shona Haslam (Cons) said: &ldquoWorking with our partners in Live Borders, the council is working hard to try and secure a major investment at Harestanes, where we hope to introduce a high level of equipment for children with additional needs including wheelchair swings, roundabouts and activity units.
The funding announcement comes off the back of the success of the opening of the new Rowan Bowland play park in Galashiels.
Councillor Sandy Aitchison (Ind), added: &ldquoThe council has a lot of work to do over the next four years to roll out this new investment but we know that when new facilities are installed, the public response to them is very positive.
&ldquoWith a greater focus on reducing childhood obesity and getting young people active, it is important that we invest money wisely to make sure that this can happen.
&ldquoCouncillors were unanimous in approving this element of the budget and I know that the whole council will want to work hard to leave a lasting legacy of improved play provision and facilities for young people.

story:

title: Buchan   s legacy lives on with launch of new Hannay novel
story:
THE first John Buchan novel in more than 70 years will be launched in Peebles later this month.
The famed author, who wrote The Thirty-Nine Steps, grew up in Tweeddale and died in 1940.
But St Andrews-based writer Robert J Harris has brought his hero Richard Hannay back to the fray in a gripping World War II adventure &ndash The Thirty?One Kings.
And a special event will be held at the John Buchan Story Museum in Peebles to mark the occasion.
The book is a fast?paced thriller that sees Hannay (first introduced in The Thirty?Nine Steps) back in service, tracking down a missing agent as the German army advances towards Paris in 1940.
Old friends and new allies join him in a helter?skelter chase across France.
Speaking ahead of the launch, author Robert J Harris said: &ldquoIt has been a privilege to bring John Buchan&rsquos wonderful characters back to life and I look forward to sharing that experience with other admirers of his in this the best of all possible settings.
As well as being a historian, journalist, soldier and public servant, Buchan was also involved in politics.
He served as the Governor General of Canada from 1935 until his death on February 11, 1940.
But he is most famous for his story The Thirty-Nine Steps &ndash an adventure novel first published in 1915.
And his legacy continues to live on with his books, and, more recently, film adaptations still proving popular.
The launch event of The Thirty-One Kings will take place at the John Buchan Story Museum in The Chambers Institution from 6pm-8pm on Wednesday, June 13.
Ian Buckingham, from the museum told the Peeblesshire News: &ldquoOur museum features many aspects of Buchan&rsquos life and his stories, and we are delighted that we can now add a further chapter to the life of Richard Hannay.
The event is free, but is ticketed.
Reserved tickets can be collected on the night of the event.
To book a ticket, contact Ian on 07835 149 706. Refreshments will also be served at the event.

title: Flaming heck  June  39 s busy at the Eastgate
story:
THEATRE bosses in Peebles are preparing for one of their busiest ever months.
June's programme offers an enticing mix of comedy, live music, world class ballet on screen, drama and film.
The bar will immediately be set high when star of TV and radio, and one of Scotland&rsquos best-loved comics, Fred Macaulay comes to Peebles on Friday (June 8).
Celebrating 30 years as a stand-up, the set features his trademark mix of personal family anecdotes with wry observations about society and politics.
It&rsquos then time for another celebration as two musicians with an equally strong following return to the Eastgate stage on June 14. After touring the world in each other&rsquos bands, writing and recording songs together, not to mention a decade of marriage, multi-award-winning musicians Heidi Talbot and John McCusker celebrate their first collaborative EP by touring as a duo for the first time.
There&rsquos further live music towards the end of the month (June 28) when the Roy Orbison &amp Buddy Holly show rolls into town. The two musical legends both grew up in the same part of Texas, and recorded their early work in the same studio &ndash with each developing a totally original and individual sound.
In this tribute to the two great artists, Darren Paige as Roy Orbison and Marc Robinson as Buddy Holly bring together a two-hour show featuring all the hits and a few earlier tracks, too.
Sandwiched between the live music, there is also outstanding live ballet on screen (June 12) when the Royal Ballet presents a brand new production of Swan Lake, with additional choreography by artist in residence Liam Scarlett.
Then, on Friday, June 15, it&rsquos the turn of stage stars of the future as Shakespeare at Traquair presents its hilarious Shakespeare Shorts pre-Fringe 2018 show featuring two knock-about plays by kids, for kids.
The Taming of the Shrew sees theatre director Kate&rsquos cast revolting, her producer perplexed and Kate herself in despair. Meanwhile, the second &lsquoshort&rsquo, Much Ado About Nothing, looks more like an episode of The Great Brexit Bakeoff, with burning buns, sinking souffl&eacutes and soggy bottoms as the play&rsquos star-crossed lovers carry on baking.
Throw in three blockbuster films for all ages on June 24 &ndash Sherlock Gnomes, The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society, and The Leisure Seeker.

title: Businessman Colin cooks up a   300 donation
story:
A PEEBLES businessman has donated &pound300 to a local cookery school.
Colin Macdonald of Brown Borthers motor company gifted the cash to You Can Cook, which works with youngsters to teach them about food and how to cook.
Colin made the donation as part of his drive to support local good causes that strive to make their communities a better place for all.
He told us: "We were delighted to support Bosco and his team in Peebles in their continuous drive to promote healthy living. We were particularly impressed with the work being done with local school children in the 'edible garden' at St Ronan&rsquos, which You Can Cook have created in a bid to educate youngsters and inspire them towards a better diet for life. Much is being done at a national level by the likes of Jamie Oliver, but the power of a local presence working tirelessly for the community reaches far-further."
Bosco Santimano, from You Can Cook added: "We would like to thank Colin for his kind contribution to the work we do in our local community."

title: NOSTALGIA  History of a Peebles blacksmith  Part Two
story:
THIS week, reader John Ker brings us the history of a Peebles blacksmith...
This photograph is one of James Ker with his blacksmiths in the early 1860s at his forge in Ker Place Northgate Peebles.
He was a blacksmith and veterinary surgeon who ran the family business in partnership with his brother Charles Tod Ker also a blacksmith who specialised in the engineering work they undertook.
The family&rsquos very long-established premises were originally at sites where the Eastgate Theatre now stands and one now occupied by a land agent in the Northgate, neighbouring the Cleikum. This must have been a favoured site well-placed beside a coaching inn on the main road North.
The 1860s saw the further development of the railways begun five years previously.
Before this Peebles lived up to its reputation of being, &ldquoAs quiet as the grave or as Peebles. With the railways came industry and people and money.
Commercial Peebles began to develop and the Northgate was no exception. Up until then the Northgate was little more than the road out of town with several pastoral tofts strung out along it. Laird Girdwood, was a larger-than-life character and also one of the prominent proprietors. He was also a member of the Peeblesshire Rifle Volunteers.
Then as now, such organisations accommodate a little social networking.
It is not surprising then that Charles Ker, also a Volunteer and his sister acquired one of these tofts from a comrade. Meanwhile James Ker lived with his wife at Red Lion House in Biggiesknowe. Their toft was more than half an acre in size with a barn whose gable end faced the street and a single-storey cottage attached. Parts of the barn were rebuilt
into a new dwelling house.
The barn itself is not without interest being the one scene of Laird Girdwood&rsquos Venison Feast to which all the residents of the Northgate were invited everyone, however, to bring his own beverage.
It was a resounding success&mdash&ldquoNever before did the rafters ring with such glee. was the reported account of the event.
A traditional forge and a modern purpose-built engineering workshop were built as well as a &lsquospec&rsquo tenement of four dwellings.
Wrought iron work was much in evidence, with a large garden behind and a rustic rockery at the front of the property. It was then given the name &lsquoKer Place&rsquo after the fashion of the time for such businessmen of which there are several examples in Peebles.
The cottage (pre 1823), which is still in place, became part of the enterprise and judging by the size of the lathe bed and fire-scorched rafters some serious work went on there.
It also incorporated James Ker&rsquos dispensary for his veterinary work. James had been a student of William Dick at his Edinburgh Veterinary College which he had established at his father&rsquos forge in Clyde Street in Edinburgh where the bus station now stands.
He obtained his diploma to practice as a veterinary surgeon and was also made a Fellow of the Edinburgh Medical Veterinary Society for his &ldquovaluable contribution to veterinary science. This may have been in connection with a product he sold commercially as &lsquoKer&rsquos Alterative Sheep Pill&rsquo.
It must have been effective since it was still being sold in the 1930s by his son, John Ker. He, also a blacksmith, had qualified as a veterinary surgeon nearly forty years after his father at what was by then called the Royal &ldquoDick Veterinary College.
James and his wife died at a young age and his brother and sister, Charles and Elizabeth, carried on the business successfully as well as raising James&rsquos family of two boys.
John Ker, as said, served his apprenticeship as a blacksmith and also qualified as a veterinary surgeon. About 1916 the smiddy closed when the farriers went to war.
John Ker served as a captain with the Royal Army Veterinary Corps and on his return practiced locally as a veterinary surgeon until he died after a short illness towards the end of 1938. The smiddy, itself, &ldquodid its bit during hostilities, by billeting troops.
It did not reopen after the war and operate at its former level of business as blacksmiths and engineers. It did, however, remain in general use and is currently a joiner&rsquos workshop.
John Ker was also the last &ldquoBoxmaster (minute secretary) of the Peebles Incorporation of Hammermen&mdashthe blacksmiths&rsquo once exclusive and powerful guild.
It fell to him to record in the minutes, rather regretfully, &ldquoThere was no meeting and no dinner held in 1927&mdashfitting, his forebear had been one of the founding signatories we believe. Times had changed, the calling had lost its prosperous and confident ambience, and that was a fact.
These events resonate with the story of Black Beauty&rsquos life over a hundred years ago in Victorian England.
Some of his memories were happy and some were very sad, none less so than those when he meets his old friend Ginger . . .

title: 40 week one-way system introduced in Jedburgh
story:
A TEMPORARY one-way system has been in introduced in Jedburgh to allow work to be carried out to a privately-owned dangerous building.
The new arrangement, which began on Monday (June 4), has seen a section of the High Street become one-way southbound from Jewellers Wynd to Canongate southbound, and a section of Exchange Street one-way northbound from High Street to Friarsgate.
This one-way system is required to extend scaffolding onto the road to allow for repairs to be carried out to the building, which has significant structural issues and needs extensive work to make it safe.
The disruption is expected to last 40 weeks, and a temporary walkway has also been introduced around the scaffolding to allow pedestrians to still use High Street and Exchange Street.
Signage is in place to make people aware of the temporary arrangement.
A joint statement by Jedburgh and District councillors Jim Brown, Scott Hamilton, Sandy Scott said: &ldquoThe High Street dangerous building is a complex and long running issue, but the council is making progress and needs to introduce this temporary one-way system to carry out further repairs.
&ldquoThe council is looking at various options for the future of the building, and a report is expected to be discussed later this year.
&ldquoWe thank townsfolk for their patience so far, and would ask they comply with the temporary one-way system.

title: Borders parking issues working group calls for evidence from public
story:
A CALL for evidence on parking issues in Borders town centres has been issued by Scottish Borders Council&rsquos Parking Issues Working Group.
The working group is currently gathering evidence and researching what happens in other local authority areas and will report back to the Executive Committee later this year with recommendations.
An online survey has now been launched to give local people and businesses the opportunity to provide evidence of any issues faced in their communities.
Councillor Gordon Edgar, Executive Member for Roads and Infrastructure and chair of the working group, said: &ldquoAs part of our evidence gathering we want to hear from people on specific places, days and times when parking is a problem. This information must be as specific as possible to ensure that we have the full picture and can compare to any existing regulations and explore potential for additional spaces, restrictions and enforcement.
The working group comprises Councillors Edgar (Ind), Andy Anderson (SNP), Carol Hamilton (Cons), Euan Jardine (Cons), Clair Ramage (SNP), Euan Robson (Lib Dem) and Robin Tatler (Ind).
The survey can be access at: https://scotborders.citizenspace/

title: Border pupils meet President and First Lady of Malawi
story:
PUPILS from a Tweeddale school made history recently after being invited to an exclusive state visit by the president and first lady of Malawi.
As a part of the Scotland/Malawi Partnership, St Ronan&rsquos Primary in Innerleithen has a committee of 11 pupils who meet monthly to promote the school and community links between their town and Thondwe.
And it was the older members of this group who were invited to be part of the visit of the president and first lady, Peter Mutharika and Gertrude Maseko &ndash which was held in Edinburgh City Chambers.
Teacher Shirley Bean, who is responsible for the group, said: &ldquoDue to the high security, the children couldn&rsquot be told of the nature of the visit until they were on the minibus bound for Edinburgh.
&ldquoSt. Ronan&rsquos was one of only two primary schools in attendance and it was a great honour for us to be involved.
The President and his entourage entered the chamber to the sound of the Malawian national anthem, before they were officially welcomed by the deputy lord provost of Edinburgh, Councillor Joan Griffiths.
There were a number of speeches by different groups sharing their partnership experiences, including charities, agriculture, health and education groups.
The government was represented by MSP Fiona Hyslop, minister for foreign affairs and culture, and both she and President Mutharika took part in a question and answer session.
Before the end of the visit, two representatives from each school were invited to join the first lady and the President for a photograph.
Freya Wilson and Joshua Inglis, the oldest boy and oldest girl from the Malawi group, represented St Ronan&rsquos.
Miss Bean added: &ldquoEach of St Ronan&rsquos pupils wore a cloth Malawi badge with the words, &lsquoMalawi The Warm Heart of Africa&rsquo and Freya presented special versions to the first lady and the president.
&ldquoThe first lady asked Freya to pin the badge on for her and the president.
&ldquoFreya held her nerve and although she found it tricky, the president&rsquos body guard stepped in and helped her out.
Keith Belleville, headteacher at St Ronan&rsquos, told us: &ldquoThe Malawi partnership is very important to us here at St Ronan&rsquos.
&ldquoIt&rsquos a great way to promote cultural differences and diversity, while giving a focus to our international charity work.
&ldquoThe strength of our association with Thondwe is that it is a whole community link and I&rsquom sure that this will continue to flourish as we share learning between our two continents.

title: Galashiels life-saver meets the four year old he saved
story:
A FORMER student from Galashiels saved a child's life by skiving a lecture.
Anthony Lenton and his classmates avoided an afternoon tutorial at Borders College to register with the Anthony Nolan Trust.
And within a few months his genetic profile proved to be an identical match for a gravelly-ill toddler 150 miles away in Aberdeenshire.
Anthony, who is now the co-manager of William Hill bookmaker's in Galashiels, told us: "We all had a dull lecture to look forward to after lunch at the College when we saw a girl from the Anthony Nolan Trust looking for people to register.
"I had no knowledge of what the Anthony Noland Trust did but we decided to take our time filling in the forms so we didn't have to go to the lecture.
"Basically, sciving a lecture was the best decision I ever made."
At just 11 months old, Finn Mackin was diagnosed with a rare and dangerous form of leukaemia after a suspicious lump was found on one of his eyes.
Tumours developed and it was considered that chemotherapy was the Stonehaven toddler's only hope.
But several unsuccessful doses of treatment failed to cure him from cancer during a four-month stay at the Royal Aberdeen Children&rsquos Hospital.
And consultants decided the only remaining option of saving Finn's life was a high-risk stem cell transplant.
During countrywide searches for donors, it was found that Anthony in Galashiels was the perfect match.
The youngster underwent a successful transplant at the end of 2015, followed by more than 50 blood transfusions, before eventually being declared cancer-free.
Finn remains cancer-free and last week he was introduced to the skiving student who saved his life.
Anthony added: "It was really emotional meeting Finn.
"There is not allowed to be any contact for two years but then Anthony Nolan&nbsppassed on my number and Finn's mum made contact.
"It turned out I was a perfect match for Finn - a 12 out of 12, which could only be bettered if he had a twin.
"I have no idea how we are so genetically matched as I'm originally from Cambridgeshire and Finn's family are all from around Aberdeen."
Stephen has now been invited to Finn's parents wedding next year.
Finn's mum Siobhan said: "Without Anthony, Finn wouldn't be here - as simple as that.
"We&rsquoll be forever thankful."
The Anthony Nolan&nbspTrust manages and recruits donors to a nationwide register to help match donors with cancer sufferers.
The charity also carries out research to help make bone marrow transplants more effective.
Amy Bartlett from Anthony Nolan said: "You could literally save somebody's life, as we've seen happen with young Finn.
"I mean this story could have been so different, but for the generosity of a complete stranger."

title: Bolton man accused of peeping Tom offence at caravan park showers
story:
A 44-year-old man has been charged under the Sexual Offences Act accused of watching a man having a shower while in a state of undress at a Melrose caravan park.
Robert Newsham is said to have observed the male doing a private act by standing on a stool and looking into the shower cubicle.
The offence is said to have happened at the shower and toilet block at Gibson Caravan Park in Melrose.
Newsham of Blackrod, Bolton, Lancashire, pleaded not guilty to breaching Section Nine of the Sexual Offences Act (Scotland).
There is also an alternative charge of threatening or abusive behaviour which he also denies.
A trial date has been set for August 16 at Selkirk Sheriff Court with an intermediate hearing on July 16.

title: Deputy First Minister marks start of Jedburgh Campus construction
story:
THE Deputy First Minister was in the Borders this week to mark the start of works on Jedburgh's new Intergenerational Community Campus.
John Swinney joined pupils from Jedburgh Grammar, Howdenburn and Parkside primary schools and Scottish Borders Councillors for the ground breaking ceremony for the innovative new facility on land at Hartrigge Park on Monday.
The Intergenerational Community Campus will replace all three schools, with provision for nursery, primary and secondary school children alongside further education.
Community facilities will include a multi-use games area, 2G hockey pitch, 3G sports pitch, 100m running track, external changing pavilion and rural skills area.
The funding for the new campus was confirmed by Mr Swinney in August 2017, as one of four projects to share &pound28m from the latest phase of the Scottish Government&rsquos &pound1.8 billion &lsquoSchools for the Future&rsquo programme.
The project is being taken forward by SBC, its development partner Hub South East Scotland and appointed main contractor BAM, while enabling works are currently being carried out by Jedburgh-based contractor RJT Excavations Ltd, providing local benefits.
The main construction will begin in the autumn, with the project on programme to open to learners by March 2020.
Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: &ldquoI would like to thank Scottish Borders Council for inviting me to help mark the start of the process which will result in a fantastic new intergenerational campus that the whole community can be proud of.
&ldquoLearning and teaching in such an innovative and inspirational setting can make a real difference to education outcomes.
&ldquoThat is why the Scottish Government is committed to improving Scotland&rsquos school estate, and through our &pound1.8 billion Schools for the Future building programme, we are providing almost &pound18 million towards this project.
Councillor Shona Haslam (Cons), SBC&rsquos Leader, said: &ldquoThis is another hugely significant day for Jedburgh.
&ldquoWhile it is hard to imagine at the moment, in two years on this site we will have a brand facility which will benefit generations of people in the town.
&ldquoExtensive consultations in the community showed the vast majority were right behind the plans for a new intergenerational campus, which will provide for 2 to 102 year olds, with further education opportunities and community facilities for the whole town.
&ldquoDuring construction, a number of community benefits will be delivered to support the local economy, with a local firm already involved in the project.

title: Safety inspections planned at Scottish Borders cemeteries
story:
SBC is to carry out safety inspections at 18 cemeteries across the area.
The local authority have said that any headstones which fail the safety test will need to be cordoned off and if possible, the owners/next of kin will be contacted.
Council leader, councillor Shona Haslam (Cons) said: &ldquoClearly this is a sensitive matter. We are very sympathetic to the issues and will ensure the work is undertaken with due respect and only where absolutely necessary. Our cemeteries are peaceful, tranquil places but we also have to make sure they are safe places for everyone.
&ldquoUnsafe headstones pose a significant risk and we must take all reasonable steps to make these areas as safe as possible.
&ldquoWhile there is no specific funding or obligation on the Council to re-instate headstones, various alternative sources of funding could be explored by communities and the Council is willing to assist wherever possible.
&ldquoIt is very unfortunate, and I understand the distress and concern that this action will cause, but the Council often has little option but to lay flat unsafe headstones which are not repaired by the owner or their next of kin.

title: Six weeks of road closures planned around Earlston for pipe works
story:
MOTORISTS in and around parts of Earlston can expect delays next week with a planned two-day road closure.
And a further six-weeks closure is scheduled to start later in the month.
From next Monday (June 11) the Mill Road between the Leader Water and the Blainslie Road junction will shut to allow for a new mains water pipe to be installed.
And from Monday, June 18, Blainslie Road itself will be closed, between the junction of the A68 and the Mill Road junction, for up to six weeks.
The road closures form part of Scottish Water&rsquos &pound4 million investment to install a 7km new water mains pipe from Newstead to Earlston.
Scott Fraser, regional corporate affairs manager at Scottish Water, said: &ldquoWe apologise to customers affected by these essential closures and endeavour to keep disruption to a minimum.
"The project aims to improve overall drinking water quality and ensure that customers in the Borders continue to enjoy clear, fresh drinking water now and in the future."
Residents' access will be maintained for the properties within both closure areas.
Barclay Smart, CWA&rsquos project manager said: &ldquoSo far we have installed over 2km of new mains and are on track to complete the work by October.
"As part of the project and to increase efficiency our alliance partner Caledonia Water Alliance (CWA) is using a technique called horizontal directional drilling to install the main.
&ldquoThis method is a minimal impact trenchless method of installing underground pipe and means less road surface has to be excavated to install the water main.
"Launching and receiving pits replace the need for a traditional construction trench, resulting in faster, less intrusive work, leading to quicker reinstatement of the road surface.
&ldquoIn this project this technique has avoided the closure of the A68 and further disruption to local communities and commuters.

title: WATCH  Child cyclist thanks HGV driver for safe overtake in Jedburgh
story:
A VIDEO of a&nbspfour-year-old cyclist who thanked a 'kind' HGV driver for safely overtaking her in Jedburgh has been viewed over 700,000 times.
Rhoda Jones was cycling on the A68 through the Scottish Borders town with her father, Tom, last week when the video was recorded on his dashcam.
Mr Jones, and his wife, from&nbspNorthamptonshire, were in Jedburgh for half-term on their bikes, with their two children on connected&nbsptrailer bikes.
The footage shows the lorry giving an extremely wide berth around the cyclists as Rhoda gives him a thumbs up and shouts 'thank you'.
A statement, published alongside the video on Twitter, read: "So often we see or share videos of awful driving around cyclists, so this textbook pass from an exceptionally patient and careful HGV driver for D&ampW Agri coming into Jedburgh deserves sharing, as does Rhoda's response!
"They're not on Twitter but we've thanked the haulier directly."

title: Woman was almost four-times legal limit on way home from supermarket
story:
A SHOPPER who drove home from a local supermarket while almost four times the legal limit has received a 16-month driving ban at Selkirk Sheriff Court.
Fifty three year old Willow Syme had initially denied driving in various streets in Peebles with a breath/alcohol reading of 87 microgrammes - the legal limit being 22 - on the evening of Friday, March 23.
But at her intermediate diet she changed her plea to guilty.
The court was told she was spotted leaving the Sainsbury's store under the influence of alcohol and police were called.
Her lawyer said the support worker was having relationship difficulties at the time.
Syme of Kitttlegairy View in Peebles, was also fined &pound300 in addition to the 16 month ban.

title: Rugby fan was five times driving limit after Earlston Sevens
story:
A rugby fan who got into her car after a drinking session following Earlston Sevens was five times the legal alcohol limit, Selkirk Sheriff Court has been told.
After travelling a short distance, Leisha Lightbody of Forthill Avenue in Jedburgh, was immediately pulled over by police officers who were on duty in Earlston's High Street on Sunday, May 6.
The 24-year-old recorded a breath/alcohol reading of 110 microgrammes - the legal limit being 22.
Lightbody - who works at Edinburgh Airport - had her disqualification period reduced to 14 months due to her immediate guilty plea and she was also fined &pound400.

title: Britain s Got Talent 2018 winner Lost Voice Guy to gig in the Scottish Borders
story:
HE&nbspcaptured the nation&rsquos hearts as Lost Voice Guy and was crowned the winner of Britain&rsquos Got Talent, but before comedian Lee Ridley performs for the Royal Family, he has&nbspa rather important engagement in the Scottish Borders this week.
The stand-up comedian, from Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, who astounded Great Britain with his hilarious comedy despite having no speech, is to perform at West Linton&rsquos Annual Comedy evening tomorrow (Thursday, June 7) at 7.30pm in the Marquee on the village's Lower Green.
The comedy evening is part of the Border village's annual Whipman Festival week.
Lee suffers from neurological condition cerebral palsy which means he can&rsquot speak, and instead pre-records his routines and plays them via a voice synthesizer on a tablet.
The first comedian ever to win the talent show and scoop &pound250,000, plus a slot at the Royal Variety Performance,&nbsphad the judges, audiences and the public in stiches with his self-deprecating brand of comedy, opening his performance with quips like &ndash &ldquoI&rsquom a struggling stand-up comedian who also struggles to stand up.
Former Whipman Calum Murray said: &ldquoThe Whipman Play Society is extremely excited to have Lee performing with us at our annual comedy evening, hosted by Over The Lynne Comedy Club.
&ldquoThis event has gown each year and is one not to be missed during the Whipman week.
&ldquoAs a fan of Britain&rsquos Got Talent myself, this year was definitely one of the best, especially for comedians.
&ldquoIt&rsquos amazing for us to be able to have such a big name this year. Lee is an extraordinary character and an inspiration to many.
&ldquoA massive thanks goes to Joan Scott, aka Jeannie Jones for organising such a successful event year after year.
&ldquoThe Whipman Play Society can&rsquot wait to see Lee on stage.
For more information, go to:&nbsp

title: Wheels in motion to help buy new community mini bus for Gala
story:
COMMUNITY transport provider Gala Wheels is issuing a plea for help to raise the final funds needed to buy a new wheelchair-adapted minibus.
Run by community development organisation, The Bridge, Gala Wheels was formed just over 10 years ago to provide affordable, accessible transport for disabled and elderly residents in the central Scottish Borders.
It runs a membership scheme, offering social transport to individuals, care homes and disability organisations, and is delivered by a dedicated team of volunteer drivers.
Gala Wheels also offers its primarily disabled and elderly customers the opportunity of social trips and excursions, as well as providing transport to health and hospital appointments and transport to respite care.
The service is subsidised by Scottish Borders Council, but Gala Wheels has to rely on donations and grants to purchase new vehicles.
Gala Wheels Executive Officer Morag Walker told us: &ldquoFollowing a successful fundraising campaign, we were delighted to receive financial pledges from both local and national charities, service users and supporters.
"Ideally, this final push for donations will help us to secure the &pound4000 we need to purchase a new vehicle before the winter and enable Gala Wheels to maintain and expand its current service."
Gala Wheels currently provides two minibuses, each seating up to seven passengers.
The busy and popular service runs seven days a week and is currently operating at maximum capacity, which is why a larger, 11-seater vehicle is needed.
They have raised more than &pound30,000 for the minibus, but still need another &pound4,000.
Speaking after paying a visit to the service, John Lamont MP said: &ldquoReducing social isolation by keeping people engaged in the community is an absolute necessity in places like the Borders.
"Community transport providers, like Gala Wheels do incredible work, without them, many people would simply not be leaving their homes.
&ldquoWhile it&rsquos good that Scottish Borders Council continues to do what it can to help with the day to day running costs, Gala Wheels still has to rely on the generosity of others and charitable trusts to upgrade its fleet.
&ldquoThe team have worked hard to raise most of the money they need and are really close to achieving that. Hopefully with a bit more publicity, the final bit of money can be found.

title: Work to start on Traquair  39 s   200k footpath trails
story:
FUNDING for a &pound200,000 project to create pathways in and around Traquair has been approved.
And work on the links to Innerleithen and the Southern Upland Way are expected to start later this month.
Forestry Commission Scotland has agreed to back the plans which will see new routes developed between Innerleithen and both Traquair village and Traquair House, a new pathway from the town to the Mountain Bike car park, and also a new trail route connecting Traquair with the Southern Upland Way.
A range of themed interpretation boards, picnic benches and perch benches will also be built as part of the project.
It is estimated that around 32 hectares of woodland will be made accessible with the new paths.
Catherine Maxwell Stuart from Traquair House said: "We are absolutely delighted that the path network is taking shape at last.
"It has been a long held desire to make Traquair more accessible by foot and particularly for local people to take advantage of the woodlands around Traquair which have previously been difficult to access.
"The new views that are being opened up with the new footpaths are really breath-taking.
"We are looking forward to making the dream become a reality.
A community consultation exercise was held in November, 2016, by the Traquair House Charitable Trust, to gauge opinion on creating new pathways.
More than 60 members of the public gave their enthusiastic support for the multi-use paths through Traquair woodlands.
Over the past 18 months a management plan was developed to produce an exciting combination of new access, interpretation and woodland management.
And the submitted plans were this week approved by Forestry Commission Scotland.
Preparatory work has already taken place over the last year in the woodlands through the approved Forest Design Plan with the felling of three woodlands and thinning of a further two woodlands to ensure work on the paths can be started straight away.
Each individual access route will be opened when completed over the next 18 months.

title: A7 driver was almost five times the legal limit
story:
A MOTORIST who was almost five times the legal alcohol limit while driving on the A7 has been banned from the road for 14 months at Selkirk Sheriff Court.
Heather Condon had a breath/alcohol count of 103 microgrammes - the legal limit being 22 - after police caught up with her at Heriot on March 9 last year.
The 42-year-old of Moss Place, Livingston, had denied the offence but was found guilty after a trial.
In addition to the disqualification period, she was fined &pound400.

title: Lowood Bridge closure  SBC release update
story:
GOOD news for motorists - council bosses have confirmed that works to Lowood Bridge are set to be complete in time for Melrose Festival Week.
The project is in its final stages and remains on schedule to be completed by Monday, June 18, the day of the Melrosian Rideout.
So far, the temporary scaffolding has been removed, which means works on the bridge deck area can start.
Repairs to the bridge's stonework are now complete, as well as resurfacing of the Waverley Road/Lowood Road junction. New electrical cabling for the traffic light system upgrade has also been installed and kerbing work has started on the Galashiels side of the bridge.
A range of kerbing, drainage and surfacing of the bridge deck will now be completed, alongside stone repair and pointing to the wingwalls on the Galashiels side of the bridge, while works are finished to install the traffic light system.
Scottish Borders Council added that an exact opening date will be announced next week.
In an update, the authority said: "We continue to appreciate the patience of motorists, local people and businesses during the closure and we are working to open the bridge as soon as possible."

title: Theresa May under fresh pressure over Brexit
story:
Theresa May was under fresh pressure from within the Cabinet after Boris Johnson warned of a Brexit &ldquomeltdown and called for &ldquoguts in exit talks.
In unguarded comments at a private dinner, the Foreign Secretary said there was a risk Brexit &ldquowill not be the one we want and would keep the UK &ldquolocked in orbit around the EU.
At the gathering of the Conservative Way Forward, a Thatcherite campaign group, he branded the Treasury the &ldquoheart of Remain and claimed negotiations were approaching a &ldquomoment of truth.
In comments captured in a recording obtained by BuzzFeed News, he said the Prime Minister was &ldquogoing to go into a phase where we are much more combative with Brussels.
He added: &ldquoYou&rsquove got to face the fact there may now be a meltdown. OK? I don&rsquot want anybody to panic during the meltdown. No panic. Pro bono publico, no bloody panic. It&rsquos going to be alright in the end.
Mr Johnson suggested Chancellor Philip Hammond&rsquos department was &ldquobasically the heart of Remain and said the UK could end up &ldquoin the customs union and to a large extent still in the single market.
The Cabinet minister was speaking to around 20 people dining in a private room after a reception at the Institute of Directors on Wednesday night.
He said: &ldquoUnless you make the change, unless you have the guts to go for the independent policy, you&rsquore never going to get the economic benefits of Brexit. You&rsquoll never get the political benefits of Brexit.
Mr Johnson said&nbspfears about the border on the island of Ireland were out of proportion.
&ldquoIt&rsquos so small and there are so few firms that actually use that border regularly, it&rsquos just beyond belief that we&rsquore allowing the tail to wag the dog in this way, he added.
&ldquoWe&rsquore allowing the whole of our agenda to be dictated by this folly.
Mr Johnson also suggested Donald Trump would &ldquogo in bloody hard and &ldquomight get somewhere in the exit talks if he was in charge.
The US president, meanwhile, has grown tired of Mrs May&rsquos &ldquoschool mistress tone, his allies have told the Daily .
His comments are the latest Brexit headache for the Prime Minister, who is in Canada for the G7 summit.
The Foreign Secretary&rsquos deputy, Sir Alan Duncan, raised eyebrows in Westminster when he floated the possibility of a referendum on the exit deal.
Mrs May also met twice with David Davis before flying out to the summit amid reports the Brexit Secretary was considering resigning unless she set a clear time limit on the temporary customs arrangement.
Friends of Mr Johnson said: &ldquoThis was a private dinner under Chatham House rules so it is sad and very disappointing that it has been covertly recorded and distributed to the media.
Michel Barnier, the EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator, is expected to hold a press conference in Brussels at around 1pm to discuss the latest round of technical talks on the exit process.
Mrs May secured approval from senior ministers for a &ldquobackstop arrangement that could keep the UK in a customs union with the EU beyond the end of 2020.
But there was no fixed deadline in the document published later, which said only the UK &ldquoexpects a final customs solution to be in place by the end of December 2021 at the latest.
The document represents the UK&rsquos counter to an EU proposal to keep Northern Ireland alone in the customs union after Brexit, which was rejected outright by Mrs May because it would draw a border down the Irish Sea.
In a letter to Tory MPs, obtained by The Times, the Prime Minister described the UK proposal as &ldquounpalatable but at worst temporary and &ldquoin no way the Government&rsquos intended or desired result.
Theresa May is facing fresh pressure over Brexit (Simon Dawson/PA)
Under the new backstop proposals, if no agreement on customs has been implemented by the end of 2020, a temporary arrangement would ensure that no &ldquotariffs, quotas, rules of origin (or) customs processes applied to UK-EU trade.
At the same time the UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.
Mrs May braced herself for possible defeat in the Commons next week on an amendment which would require her to try to negotiate a permanent customs union with the remaining EU.
The PM has rejected most of the amendments made to the EU (Withdrawal) Bill made by peers, accepting only one in full.
Anti-Brexit campaign group Best for Britain has released an open letter to voters calling on them to join the &ldquonational conversation aimed at resolving the &ldquonightmare of Brexit.
It claims public opinion is shifting on Brexit and published a &ldquoroadmap to a fresh vote with a summer of campaigning planned across 100 constituencies.
